title: EDR vs MDR
content: Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) focuses on local threat detection, while Managed Detection and Response (MDR) adds 24/7 monitoring and expert analysis.

title: SOC Tiers
content: Security Operations Centers (SOCs) are often structured in tiers: Tier 1 handles triage, Tier 2 investigates, and Tier 3 performs threat hunting and advanced response.

title: MITRE ATT&CK
content: The MITRE ATT&CK framework maps adversary tactics and techniques, aiding threat detection and incident response.

title: SIEM Function
content: Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) systems aggregate logs, detect anomalies, and support compliance reporting.

title: Firewall Rule Logic
content: Firewall rules evaluate traffic based on source, destination, port, and protocol, enforcing access control policies.

title: IPsec VPN
content: IPsec VPNs secure network traffic using encryption and authentication, commonly used for site-to-site and remote access.

title: Red Teaming
content: Red teaming simulates real-world attacks to test defenses, improve detection, and strengthen incident response capabilities.

title: Phishing Indicators
content: Common phishing indicators include mismatched URLs, urgent language, unexpected attachments, and spoofed sender addresses.

title: Patch Management
content: Patch management ensures timely updates to software and systems, reducing exposure to known vulnerabilities.

title: Least Privilege
content: The principle of least privilege restricts user access to only what's necessary, minimizing potential damage from compromise.

title: Ubiquitous Encryption
content: Modern security models advocate encrypting data in transit and at rest, even within trusted internal networks.

title: Secure Boot
content: Secure Boot ensures that only trusted software is loaded during system startup, protecting against rootkits and firmware tampering.

title: DNS over HTTPS (DoH)
content: DoH encrypts DNS queries to prevent eavesdropping and manipulation, enhancing privacy and integrity.

title: Threat Intelligence Feeds
content: Threat intelligence feeds provide real-time indicators of compromise (IOCs) and tactics used by threat actors.

title: Hardware Security Modules (HSMs)
content: HSMs are physical devices that securely manage cryptographic keys and perform encryption operations.

title: Cloud Shared Responsibility Model
content: In cloud environments, providers secure the infrastructure while customers are responsible for data, identity, and access controls.

title: Security Awareness Training
content: Regular training helps users recognize phishing, social engineering, and unsafe behaviors, reducing human risk factors.

title: Data Loss Prevention (DLP)
content: DLP systems monitor and restrict sensitive data movement to prevent leaks via email, cloud, or removable media.

title: OAuth 2.0
content: OAuth 2.0 enables secure delegated access, allowing apps to act on behalf of users without exposing credentials.

title: Security Policy Lifecycle
content: Effective security policies require drafting, approval, enforcement, periodic review, and revision to stay relevant.

title: Digital Forensics
content: Digital forensics involves collecting, preserving, and analyzing electronic evidence for investigations and legal proceedings.

title: Security Onion
content: Security Onion is a free, open-source Linux distro for threat hunting, enterprise security monitoring, and log analysis.

title: Kerberos Authentication
content: Kerberos uses tickets and symmetric encryption to authenticate users in a secure, centralized manner.

title: NIST Cybersecurity Framework
content: The NIST CSF organizes cybersecurity activities into five functions: Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, and Recover.

title: Air-Gapped Systems
content: Air-gapped systems are physically isolated from networks to prevent remote access and reduce attack surface.
